Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Arc Flash Detection in Photovoltaic DC Arrays Using Wavelets

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objectives and Approaches
The objective of this research is to experimentally determine the feasibility of wavelet theory to detect arc flash in photovoltaic energy systems as a warning of incipient arc fault. The approach is to identify, develop, and verify wavelet transform algorithms, implement the technique in digital signal processing hardware, build an arc flash test chamber, and test using the photovoltaic array infrastructure at Texas A&M University. From small-scale residential systems to large-scale utility systems, arcing poses serious threats to human safety and hinders widespread adoption of photovoltaic energy.

Intellectual Merit
This project will conduct experimental verification through proof-of-concept design and testing of the efficacy of the wavelet transform, potentially transforming how arc fault detection is conducted. The proposed research is transformative because present state-of-the-art methods can only detect series arc faults by sensing the current in a direct current system and relying upon frequency or time-domain pattern recognition algorithms rather than fundamental signal decomposition.

Broader impacts
The proposed method senses the bus voltage and uses simpler, less expensive sensors than those needed to current, thus lowering the cost of safe, reliable photovoltaic energy. Use of these concepts has broad applications to any direct-current system, including microgrid, building systems, server systems and telecom systems. The PI has a history of technology transfer, is active in relevant standards development (UL 1699B), and has a demonstrated commitment to educating a diverse cleantech/greentech workforce. This project will offer students hands-on instrumentation training as well as opportunities for research analysis and publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Arc faults in photovoltaic and other electrical systems create hazards that can lead to property damage, electrocution, and even death. While arc detection for AC electrical systems is well established technology, readily available, and even mandated in certain jurisdictions, detection of arcs in photovoltaic systems remains a challenge. This project proposed and investigated a new method for detecting arcs. Moreover, the method investigated is capable of detecting sparking, the dielectric breakdown events that occur before a sustained arc. Early detection of these insipient events can lead to faster response to remediate the underlying problems.

 

This project experimentally determined the fundamental feasibility of applying wavelet theory to detect arc and arc flash in a photovoltaic (PV) direct-current (DC) array. Detecting arcs and arc flash is difficult because unlike a bolted “hard short” fault, arcs and arcflash in PV and other finite energy systems may not draw sufficiently high RMS current to trip a thermal or magnetic circuit breaker, particularly under low light (reduced generation) conditions. Further, in a PV system, the distributed capacitance of the PV modules attenuates the voltage signature associated with an arc flash, which could make it extremely difficult to sense an arc flash even if the wavelet method is very good at detecting the arc flash. The experimental validation was implemented in low-cost hardware to demonstrate that is could be feasible to develop this technology into a commercially viable product.

 

In addition, the project developed a methodology to test arc detector technology. Testing technology for photovoltaic systems is difficult because the operation of the system depends on exogenous meteorological effects including ambient temperature, amount of sunlight, and others. Thus, it is nearly impossible to create a repeatable test scenario. Further, photovoltaic systems contain power electronic devices like dc power optimizers and inverters that generate noise that can appear similar to an arc or mask the existence of an arc. False trips and no detection are problems with existing dc arc detection methods. The project investigated a method in which pre-recorded waveforms are stored in a computer then combined in arbitrary ways to emulate a limitless number of system configurations. Replayed through an amplifier and coupling circuit, this signal can then be applied to an arc detector to test for effectiveness in a scientifically repeatable way.

 

The intellectual merit of the project is the experimental validation of the wavelet transform data processing tool as a means to detect arc flash as a precursor to a sustained arc fault. This technique provides an early warning of incipient electrical arc fault before a destructive fire or personnel shock hazard can occur. The proposed research is transformative because present state-of-the-art methods rely upon frequency or time-domain pattern recognition algorithms rather than fundamental signal decomposition. Because arc fault detection is becoming a requirement for the electrical energy industry, the proposed research is immediately translational into a commercial product either as IP for embedding into other system components, a chipset to be added into other system hardware, or a self-contained dedicated detection module.

 

Broader impacts of the proposed research include new techniques for use by the electrical energy industry. Use of these concepts has broad applications to any direct-current system, including DC microgrid, dc building system, dc server system, or dc telecom system. In addition, arc flash detection will be imperative in the use of wearable personal power systems for smart clothing and wearable computers.  Results from this project are being disseminated to the industry through technical publications. The PI serves on standards creation committees which provides additional pathways for dissemination. At the University, eight students were involved in this research project, which provided training in technologies applicable to the photovoltaic industry and beyond.
